structured_data.name: Global CO2 emissions from cement production
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable dataset files (CSV and Excel formats) from Zenodo repository
structured_data.description: A comprehensive dataset documenting global CO2 emissions from cement production covering the period 1880–2021. Created by Robbie Andrew at CICERO Center for International Climate Research. The dataset includes process emissions from decomposition of carbonates in cement clinker production (~1.7 Gt CO2 in 2021) and excludes combustion emissions from fossil fuels used in production. Data are derived from USGS statistics, UNFCCC Annex I country submissions in Common Reporting Format, and country-specific methodologies. The May 2022 release (220516) includes updated data from USGS and UNFCCC sources, with cement production data for 2021 available for multiple countries including Germany. The dataset is updated periodically with supplementary releases planned.
structured_data.granularity: National (country-level data for all countries including Germany)

structured_data.name: EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) data viewer
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface (Tableau dashboard) with downloadable complete dataset available on EEA's datahub; data extracted from European Commission Union Registry website and auction platforms (EEX and ICE)
structured_data.description: The EU ETS data viewer provides aggregated emissions trading data from the European Commission's Union Registry website, covering verified emissions, allowances allocated, and surrendered units. The dataset includes data from more than 16,000 stationary installations, 1,600 aircraft operators, and 2,600 maritime operators across EU member states including Germany. Data is aggregated by country, main activity type, and year. The viewer was published on 15 September 2025 and includes data extracted as of 1 July 2025. Historical scope estimates for 2005-2012 are provided to reflect the evolving scope of the EU ETS. Background materials, data quality notes, and technical reports are available to support data interpretation.

structured_data.name: Schadstofffreisetzungs- und -verbringungsregister (PRTR)
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface at www.thru.de; UBA Data Cube for data from 2007-2022; Annual reporting by industrial facilities to UBA
structured_data.subsector: Manufacturing Industries and Construction - Metal Production and Processing
structured_data.description: The Pollutant Release and Transfer Register (PRTR) is maintained by the German Federal Environment Agency (UBA) and collects annual emissions data reported by industrial facilities in the metal sector. The dataset covers emissions to air, water, and soil, as well as waste disposal and wastewater treatment. It includes data from iron and steel production, non-ferrous metal extraction, foundries, and metal processing industries. Data is available from 2007 onwards, with annual updates. The register is based on three legal frameworks: the UNECE PRTR Protocol (2003), EU Regulation 166/2006/EG, and the German PRTR Act (2007). Data is made publicly accessible through the UBA and forwarded to the European Commission.
structured_data.granularity: National (Germany) with facility-level reporting aggregated by operational site

decision_log.summary: Plan for Germany with 30 structured queries.

decision_log.summary: Reviewed 3 documents for Germany IPPU sector data. The first document (Zenodo cement dataset) is a global cement emissions dataset with Germany-specific data mentioned, highly relevant for IPPU. The second document (EEA ETS viewer) is an EU-wide emissions trading system dashboard with potential Germany data but appears to have technical issues and focuses on ETS-covered installations rather than comprehensive IPPU. The third document (UBA metal industry emissions) is a German government source on metal industry emissions from the PRTR register, directly relevant to IPPU and appears to contain structured data access points.
decision_log.reasoning: Two documents show strong promise for IPPU data extraction. The Zenodo cement dataset explicitly mentions Germany in its 2021 data updates and provides structured CSV data on process emissions from cement production (a key IPPU subsector). The UBA metal industry page is from Germany's official environmental agency and references structured data sources (PRTR register, Data Cube) with emissions data for metal production facilities. Both are authoritative sources with clear data access pathways. The EEA ETS viewer, while potentially useful, has technical issues and focuses on trading system data rather than comprehensive IPPU inventory data.

decision_log.summary: Three credible data sources have been identified for Germany's GHGI, covering industrial process emissions (cement and metal production) and energy sector emissions through the EU ETS. All sources are from official or internationally recognized institutions. The data is national-level, which is appropriate for GHGI purposes. However, the cement production dataset (Zenodo) is global and requires country-specific extraction, while the ETS and PRTR sources are Germany-specific. The sources collectively address key IPPU and energy sectors but lack explicit linkage to Germany's official National Inventory Report (NIR) submission to UNFCCC.
decision_log.reasoning: While the identified sources are credible and relevant, a deeper investigation is warranted before full acceptance because: (1) The Zenodo cement dataset requires verification that Germany-specific data can be reliably extracted and that it aligns with Germany's official GHGI methodology; (2) The ETS data viewer needs confirmation of its completeness relative to Germany's GHGI reporting obligations and whether it covers all required sectors/subsectors; (3) The PRTR source needs clarification on whether it covers all IPPU categories required for GHGI or only metal production; (4) Most importantly, Germany's official National Inventory Report (NIR) or equivalent GHGI submission document should be located to ensure alignment with UNFCCC reporting standards. A targeted deep dive can confirm data compatibility and identify any gaps before proceeding to full data extraction.

decision_log.justification: The UBA's climate/emissions topic page is the most likely entry point to discover: (1) Germany's official NIR submissions, (2) GHGI baseline reports, (3) sectoral emissions data including IPPU, and (4) links to historical data archives. Crawling this section will systematically discover all related pages for cement, metals, and industrial process emissions.
decision_log.refinement_details_processed: Conduct targeted deep dive investigations: (1) Access the Zenodo dataset directly to confirm Germany-specific cement production and process emissions data for recent years (2019-2022) and verify alignment with UNFCCC CRF format; (2) Explore the EEA ETS data viewer to confirm coverage of Germany's industrial installations and verify that data can be disaggregated by sector/subsector as needed for GHGI; (3) Access the UBA PRTR database (www.thru.de) to confirm scope of metal production coverage and identify any gaps in IPPU sector coverage; (4) Search for Germany's official National Inventory Report (NIR) submission to UNFCCC, likely available on UBA website or UNFCCC portal, to establish the authoritative GHGI baseline and identify any additional required data sources. Suggested search: 'Germany National Inventory Report UNFCCC site:umweltbundesamt.de' or 'Germany NIR GHGI UNFCCC submission'.

decision_log.summary: Reviewed 3 documents for Germany IPPU sector data. The first document (Zenodo cement dataset) is a global cement emissions dataset with Germany-specific data points mentioned, but focuses on process emissions from cement production rather than comprehensive IPPU coverage. The second document (EEA ETS viewer) is an EU-wide emissions trading system dashboard with potential Germany data, but the snippet shows a technical error and lacks direct IPPU-specific content. The third document (UBA metal industry emissions) is from Germany's Federal Environment Agency and covers metal industry emissions through the PRTR register, which is highly relevant to IPPU but appears to focus on pollutant releases rather than greenhouse gas inventory data. Overall, moderate promise with the UBA source being most directly relevant to German industrial emissions.
decision_log.reasoning: The UBA document is a direct German government source on industrial emissions with structured data access (PRTR register and Data Cube mentioned). The Zenodo cement dataset explicitly includes Germany data for 2021 and provides structured CSV files. The EEA ETS viewer, despite the technical error in the snippet, is documented as providing aggregated emissions data by country and activity type, with downloadable datasets available. All three sources show promise for extracting IPPU-relevant data, though the UBA source appears most directly aligned with German GHGI IPPU sector reporting.

decision_log.summary: Three credible data sources have been identified for Germany's GHGI reporting, covering key industrial emission sectors (cement production, energy industries via ETS, and metal production). All sources are from established government agencies or internationally recognized research institutions. The data includes both process emissions and verified emissions trading data at national level, which is appropriate for GHGI purposes. Sources provide access to structured datasets with clear methodologies and historical coverage.
decision_log.reasoning: The extracted data meets all ACCEPT criteria: (1) Official national GHGI activity data for Germany is available from government sources (UBA PRTR, EEA ETS); (2) Data covers key emission categories (cement, steel/iron, energy industries); (3) Sources are highly credible (government agencies, international research institutions); (4) National-level granularity is appropriate for GHGI purposes and sufficient for inventory compilation. The search plan has successfully identified authoritative sources that will support Germany's GHGI reporting. No further deep dives are needed as the data quality and relevance are established.
